column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: This year, Coles also launched the Dairy Farm Sustainability Accelerator Fund, which allocates $1.5 million annually for FY24 and FY25. Each eligible Coles dairy farmer can apply for funding of between $7,500 and $50,000 annually to accelerate meaningful sustainability change across the group. Projects from the fund will focus on reducing greenhouse gas emissions, improving soil nutrients and quality, water management, biodiversity and animal welfare.
column20: Dairy Farm Sustainability Accelerator Fund, Coles Dairy Farmer, Reducing Greenhouse Gas Emissions

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: During this time, Coles created a Northern Victorian dairy farmer payment that gave Ryan some financial relief, which meant he could purchase fodder for his cattle to help replenish stock lost due to flooding. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs been refreshing to have people from Coles just sit down with us and take the time to find out what was happening and how they could best support us.Ã¢ÂÂ

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: This Policy is based on the Five Freedoms framework to address the welfare of farmed animals by minimising negative experiences. Coles recognises that all farmed animals are sentient beings. We acknowledge the Five Domains as a model to inform this Policy, to enable animals to lead a Ã¢ÂÂlife worth livingÃ¢ÂÂ within productive livestock systems.
column20: Five Freedoms Framework, Farmed Animals, Life Worth Living

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: For over a decade, Coles has worked with the RSPCA Approved Farming Scheme (the Scheme), an independent certification focused on farm animal welfare. The Scheme aims to improve the welfare of AustraliaÃ¢ÂÂs farm animals by working with farmers to set detailed animal welfare standards supported by a stringent assessment and certification process.
column20: RSPCA Approved, Farming Scheme, Independent Certification

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Established in 2014, the Coles Farm Program applies to suppliers of Coles Own Brand cage-free shell eggs, GRAZE beef and GRAZE lamb, and our Dairy Direct Sourcing Model. Under the program, farmers must meet strict animal husbandry requirements and adhere to relevant standards, such as the GRAZE Grass-fed Standard, the Egg Standards Australia Level 3 standard or Milk Purchase Agreements.
column20: Coles Farm program, Coles Own Brand, Graze Beef and Graze Lamb

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Valley Park made the ethical and sustainability-led decision to never have layer hens in cages, instead allowing hens to live in free-range systems. Over the last year, Valley Park has grown its supply of eggs to Coles by 45%, following investment in new farms and 11 new cage-free (barn) sheds. This partnership with Coles enabled the launch of its new cage-free shell eggs range, which produced approximately 150,000 dozen a week in volume for Valley Park in FY23.
column20: Valley Park, Free-Range System, Layer Hens

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: GRAZE beef is delivered in partnership with Australian farmers. GRAZE cattle are selected to high standards, grass-fed, free to roam on pastures and have no added hormones. The Coles Grass-fed Standard covers our requirements on feed and water, traceability, animal welfare and low-stress stock-handling practices.
column20: GRAZE Beef and Lamb, Australian Farmers Partnership, Coles Grass-Fed Standard

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: This year, we partnered with Amaze, participating in the Ã¢ÂÂHoodie UpÃ¢ÂÂ campaign to celebrate the autism community and help raise funds to deliver vital support to Autistic people and their families. We also worked with Amaze to launch our Autism Support Hub for leaders and team members. Coles is also actively listening and codesigning our digital channels with the disability community Ã¢ÂÂ 212 people with disabilities were included in user testing of the Coles website, mobile app and other digital assets in FY23.
column20: Hoodie Up, Autism Community, Autism Support Hub for Leaders

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Coles Own Brand strengthened its commitment to accessibility through a partnership with Get Skilled Access in FY23. Focus groups were conducted with a diverse cohort of people with disabilities to evaluate the accessibility of selected products. Lessons and recommendations have already led to improved accessibility of 45 Coles Own Brand products, including the improved ease of opening for six seed oil products, by significantly reducing the force required to open the bottles. This accessibility improvement was implemented after focus group participants voiced their experience of challenges with opening bottles and jars. A plan has been put in place to continue accessibility improvements in FY24.
column20: Coles Own Brand, Get Skilled Access, Diverse Cohort of People with Disabilities

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column8: Everyone is Welcome at Our Table
column13: In February and March 2023, Coles was a presenting partner of WorldPride and Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras, and we launched our hero campaign, Ã¢ÂÂEveryone is welcome at our tableÃ¢ÂÂ, which provided the catalyst for our stores across the country to activate, celebrate and show support. Our partnership centred on the well-being of our team members and the millions of customers they serve daily and demonstrating our support for diversity and inclusion. We want everyone to feel comfortable being themselves at work or shopping in our stores and aim to support positive mental health outcomes.
column20: WorldPride and Sydney Gas and Lesbian Maral Gras, Hero Campaign, Everyone is welcome at our table

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: With a focus on supporting and growing regional and First Nations LGBTQI+ representation, more than 100 team members came to Sydney to celebrate and be involved in critical events across the festival. We also used this campaign to raise funds for our National LGBTQI+ community partner, Pride Cup. During the year, we partnered with Pride in Health + Wellbeing (PIHW) to launch the Coles Grant, a two-year PIHW membership to help smaller organisations provide more LGBTQ-inclusive care.
column20: First Nations LGBTQI+ Representation, Pride Cup, Coles Grant

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Our Pride@Coles team member network continues to grow, championing LGBTQI+ inclusion in the workplace and beyond. It includes active participation in Pride events across Australia, such as IDAHOBIT, Midsumma Pride March and Chillout Daylesford (Victoria), Port Douglas Pride (Queensland), Perth PrideFEST (Western Australia), Wagga Wagga Mardi Gras and Newcastle Pride (New South Wales).

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: In FY23, Coles provided over $250,000 in sports equipment grants to 73 Little Athletics centres across Australia, taking the total contribution of Little Athletics grants to over $2.2 million since 2018. We also raised $150,000 for the Coles Little Athletics Community Fund through the Little Athletics Banana A-Peel in May 2023. In addition, hundreds of our supermarkets continued to team up with their local Little Athletics Centres, donating thousands of bananas each week throughout the season to encourage healthy eating and supporting grassroots initiatives like Coles Community Round.
column20: Sports Equipment Grants, Little Athletic Grants, Coles Community Round

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs

Together, these efforts will support children and their families and contribute much-needed funds for ongoing research to improve healthcare outcomes for children, including childhood cancer, enhanced patient care and experience and cutting-edge medical equipment.

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: In FY23, ColesÃ¢ÂÂ fundraising campaign for FightMND raised more than $8.6 million through sales of Big Freeze 9 beanies in our Supermarkets and selected Coles Express stores, donations from the sale of more than 90 Coles Own Brand Australian Fresh Pork products, as well as Peters Ice Cream Icy Pole Lemonade 8-packs, and customer donations at Coles Supermarkets, Coles Liquor stores and Coles Online. The funds will support research and care initiatives for people with Motor Neurone Disease (MND).

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: The Coles Healthy Kicks program motivates children between six and 12 years to become more physically active, eat nutritious food and develop a healthy mind and body while having fun with others. This year, we commenced Coles Healthy Kicks Camps and introduced Coles Healthy Kicks curriculum directly into 3,000 schools.

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Through the donation of unsold, edible food, our partnerships with SecondBite and Foodbank help Coles to improve access to food for vulnerable Australians. The food is redistributed through agencies and community food programs and, in FY23, provided the equivalent of 40.1 million meals. We also reached a significant milestone with SecondBite. Since 2011, Coles has donated more than 200 million meals.\t

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs

Stores can provide gift cards or donate products to support local events and fundraising initiatives. column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column8: New South Wales and Victoria Flooding
column13: In November 2022, when devastating floods hit towns in New South Wales and Victoria, our local stores donated essential products, including cereal, water, milk, packaged items and pet food, to flood-affected residents. Coles Online delivered more than 7,500 essential groceries and sanitary products to the evacuation centre at Forbes High School and provided hampers to residents of the flood-hit town of Eugowra, in New South Wales.
column20: New South Wales and Victoria, Local Store Donation, Flood-Affected Residents

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: In Victoria, we donated 44 pallets of essential groceries, nappies and cleaning products to the local Emergency Relief Centre in Shepparton, and five pallets were delivered to the Njernda Aboriginal Corporation in Echuca for Indigenous residents. Coles also worked with the charity Housing Justice to provide care packs to residents forced to relocate from Rochester.
column20: Victoria, Local Emergency Relief Centre, Njernda Aboriginal Corporation, Indigenous Residents

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Coles supported the Bravery Trust by raising $168,000 as part of a campaign ahead of ANZAC Day, donating 50 cents from the sale of Coles Bakery biscuits and cookies. Customers were also able to donate in-store at Coles checkouts. Coles provided gift cards to Bravery Trust to help around 100 veterans and their families buy emergency food and groceries.

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Coles has supported Guide Dogs Australia for over 40 years, making it our longest-running community partnership. In that time, more than $14 million has been raised through the Coin Collection Dogs placed in our Supermarkets and Coles Liquor stores, as well as other community fundraising initiatives, which have helped Guide Dogs to assist Australians living with low vision or blindness.
column20: Guide Dogs Australia, Coin Collection Dogs, Supermarkets and Coles Liquor

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Through the Ã¢ÂÂLove your LandÃ¢ÂÂ campaign, Coles Liquor raised over $160,000 over a weekend in March 2023, donating 25 cents from eligible transactions at Liquorland to support Clean Up Australia. The funds will keep creating and distributing free Clean Up kits to assist volunteers in cleaning up their local communities and include bags for general waste and recycling, protective gloves, high-visibility vests and sharps containers to keep volunteers safe.
